intro: Cracca polyphylla, commonly known as the many-leafed cracca, is a flowering plant native to the eastern United States. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its finely divided, fern-like leaves. The plant produces small, yellowish-white flowers arranged in umbels, typical of the family. Cracca polyphylla is often found in moist, shaded woodlands and thrives in rich, loamy soils. Its botanical features make it an attractive addition to native plant gardens and ecological restoration projects.
